tn.text: Parallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_poetry]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
Possible meanings are 1) David wrote the psalm or 2) the psalm is about David or 3) the psalm is in the style of David's psalms.

tn.ref: do not rebuke me in your anger ... do not punish me in your wrath
tn.text: These phrases mean basically the same thing and the idea is repeated for emphasis. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

The severity of Yahweh's punishment of the writer is spoken of as if Yahweh had shot arrows into the writer. AT: "Your punishment is as painful as if you had shot arrows into me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

Yahweh's punishment of the writer is spoken of as if Yahweh was smashing the writer with his hand. Here, "hand" refers to Yahweh's power. AT: "your power knocks me down" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
David continues describing what his guilt and shame does to his body. He uses hyperbole to emphasize the effects of this lesson.

tn.ref: there is no health in my bones because of my sin
tn.text: Here "my bones" represents the body of the writer. AT: " my whole body is diseased because of my sin" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
The writer's iniquities are spoken of as if they are a flood of water that covers him. AT: "my iniquities cover me like a flood" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: they are a burden too heavy for me
tn.text: The writer's iniquities are spoken of as if they are a heavy load that he cannot lift. AT: "they are like a load that is too heavy for me to lift" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
David continues describing what his guilt and shame does to his body. He uses hyperbole to emphasize the effects of this lesson.

tn.ref: My wounds are infected and smell
tn.text: Here "smell" refer to his sores having a bad smell that is associated with rotting flesh. AT: "My wounds are infected and stink as they rot" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
The pain of the writer's wounds have caused him to be bent over as if he were an old, feeble man. AT: "I am bent over in pain" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
The writer's is so sick with fever that it is as if he is burning inside. AT: "My body is burning with fever" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: there is no health in my flesh
tn.text: Here "my flesh" refers to the writer. AT: "I am completely sick" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
The writer's illness is so severe that it is as if a huge weight is pressing down on him. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Here "my heart" refers to the writer. AT: "my anguish" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

Here "my heart" refers to the writer. It may be helpful to state that the writer desires good health. AT: "My strongest desires" or "that I desire you to heal me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: my groanings are not hidden from you
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "you are able to see all my moans of sorrow" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
This idiom means his heart beats intensely. AT: "My heart beats loudly" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
"I become very weak"
"I can no longer see well"
The plots of the writer's enemies are spoken of as if they were traps that they had set to catch him like an animal. AT: "set traps to catch me" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: speak destructive words and say deceitful words
tn.text: These two phrases mean basically the same thing and emphasize the hurtful nature of what these people say. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: I am like a deaf man ... hear nothing ... does not hear
tn.text: The first lines of verse 13 and 14 use a simile to present the same image of the deaf man. The writer is so sick that he cannot hear. (See:  [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])

tn.ref: I am like a mute man ... says nothing ... has no reply
tn.text: The second lines of verses 13 and 14 use a simile to present the image of the mute man. The writer is so sick that he cannot speak. (See:  [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
a person who cannot speak
Possible meanings are 1) "you will answer me" or 2) "you will answer my enemies."
"will not delight over my trouble"

Here "my foot" represents the writer. The slipping of his foot is a metaphor that refers to the writer's troubles and misfortunes. AT: "If I make mistakes that cause me trouble" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

Possible meanings for this metaphor are 1) "I am so sick that I am about to die" or 2) "I will soon be ruined." It may be best not to interpret the metaphor in the text. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"I am always in pain"

tn.ref: But my enemies are numerous ... are many
tn.text: These two phrases mean basically the same thing. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: They repay me evil for good
tn.text: The actions of the writer's enemies are spoken of as a financial transaction where they gave him evil things in exchange for good things. The abstract nouns "evil" and "good" can be stated as actions. AT: They give me bad actions in exchange for my good actions for them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
The way the writer's enemies accuse him is spoken of as if they were throwing accusations at him like rocks. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
The writers desire for what is good is spoken of as if he were running after good things. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: Do not abandon me ... do not stay far away from me
tn.text: These two phrases have very similar meanings. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: do not stay far away from me
tn.text: Because Yahweh has not yet answered the writer's request, he speaks of Yahweh as if Yahweh were standing far away from the writer. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
God is spoken of as if he is running to the writer to help him. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
The abstract noun "salvation" can be stated as an action. AT: "you are the one who saves me" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
